data.text: Years ago met a German touring cyclist in Spain who said he could be going around the world...or maybe not...he thought making big plans was for people who needed big plans and he didn't. He had an old, steel frame, steel rim wheels, bike. He said he preferred to walk up hills with a heavy bike to riding up hills with unreliable one. Basically any bike will do but a very cheap, heavy, bike will probably last longer than a light expensive one.

data.author: John Bresnahan

data.text: It looks absolutely fine. As others have said, ANY bike can be used. I notice that it has braze-ons for a front carrier. There are four things worth saying: 1 - depending on where you're going, you might want to have a lower gear on the freewheel/cassette for those mega-steep ascents. (Freewheels are probably better for touring: they can be removed easily with a simple tool and you don't need a chain whip. They are available in touring sizes of up to 34-12.) 2 - the luggage you take will have a huge bearing on your experience. Take as little as possible and reduce the weight you're carrying to the absolute minimum. 3 - replace/service all the major bearings and have a wheel-builder check the wheels over. Replace the chain and brake blocks before you go and run them in for a few miles. Lube everything. Consider Slime for the tyres. Find the length of the spokes and carry 2 of each size + spare nipples. Repairing your bike is all part of the joy of touring ... but it's a bit more joyous when you don't need to. 4 - think about visibility. I saw a touring biker the other day with bright yellow panniers ... and I saw the panniers first! I have a yellow backpack for cycling. It's big enough to carry a few essentials like snacks, sunglasses etc. and it's VERY visible.
